L1: # Agent Task
L2: 
L3: Task id: tumor-vaccine-ici
L4: Task title: mRNA tumor sensitization for checkpoint blockade
L5: Reference paper: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade
L6: Reference URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-09006-8
L7: 
L8: ## Objective
L9: Read the report and produce all required JSON outputs that satisfy their schemas.
L10: 
L11: ## Inputs On Disk
L12: - Report: `input/report.md`
L13: - Schemas: in `schemas/`
L14: 
L15: ## Required Outputs
L16: - `output/study_overview.json` (schema: `schemas/study_overview.schema.json`)
L17: - `output/quantitative_findings.json` (schema: `schemas/quantitative_findings.schema.json`)
L18: - `output/claim_audit.json` (schema: `schemas/claim_audit.schema.json`)
L19: - `output/public_summary.json` (schema: `schemas/public_summary.schema.json`)
L20: 
L21: ## Constraints
L22: - Do not invent source facts; derive calculations only from values in the report.
L23: - Use line refs as `L<number>` where required.
L24: - Where quotes are required, copy exact report snippets.
L25: - For calculation outputs, line_refs must include every report line used for equations, constants, and numeric substitutions.
L26: - Use relative paths only.
L27: - Never use absolute paths.
L28: - Never use `..` in paths.
L29: - Write valid JSON only.
L30: 
L31: ## Completion
L32: Respond with a checklist of written output files.
L33: After the checklist, stop. Do not call more tools.
report.md

study_overview.schema.json

L1: # Structured Paper Report: Tumor Sensitization by mRNA Vaccination
L2: 
L3: ## Citation
L4: - Title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade
L5: - Journal: Nature
L6: - Year: 2025
L7: - DOI: 10.1038/s41586-025-09006-8
L8: - Source URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-09006-8
L9: 
L10: ## One-Paragraph Context
L11: Immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) can produce durable responses in some cancers, but many tumors remain non-responsive due to weak antigen presentation or poor immune priming. The paper investigates whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.
L12: 
L13: ## Study Design Snapshot
L14: - Preclinical arm: multiple murine tumor models with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.
L15: - Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.
L16: - Mechanistic probes: immunopeptidomics, transcriptomics, and perturbation controls (including IFNAR1 blockade and non-mRNA particle controls).
L17: 
L18: ## Cohorts and Scenarios
L19: 1. Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy): 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments.
L20: 2. Mouse control cohort (vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle): 84 tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls.
L21: 3. Human retrospective metastatic cohort: 130 patients total.
L22: 4. Human vaccinated subgroup: 43 patients.
L23: 5. Human unvaccinated subgroup: 87 patients.
L24: 
L25: ## Quantitative Findings
L26: | Metric | Vaccine/Combination Arm | Comparator | Interpretation |
L27: |---|---:|---:|---|
L28: | Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |
L29: | Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape |
L30: | Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |
L31: | Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |
L32: | PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable |
L33: | Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change | 1.8x | 1.0x | Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy |
L34: 
L35: ## Controls and Null/Conditional Results
L36: - Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models.
L37: - ICI-only treatment had limited activity in low-immunogenic baseline settings.
L38: - Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.
L39: - Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
L40: 
L41: ## Mechanistic Chain Proposed by Authors
L42: 1. Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
L43: 2. Interferon-associated antigen processing and presentation pathways increase.
L44: 3. A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.
L45: 4. PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.
L46: 5. Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.
L47: 
L48: ## Caveats and Threats to Validity
L49: - The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
L50: - Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
L51: - Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
L52: - Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
L53: - Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
L54: 
L55: ## Practical Takeaway
L56: The study supports a biologically coherent hypothesis that intratumoral mRNA vaccination can prime tumors for stronger ICI responses, but prospective randomized studies are required before clinical protocol changes are justified.

L1: {
L2:   "paper": {
L3:     "title": "SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade",
L4:     "doi": "10.1038/s41586-025-09006-8",
L5:     "publication_year": 2025,
L6:     "domain": "oncology-immunology",
L7:     "study_type": "preclinical+retrospective"
L8:   },
L9:   "core_question": "Can intratumoral mRNA vaccination sensitize tumors to immune checkpoint blockade and does that align with outcomes in vaccinated patients receiving ICI?",
L10:   "datasets_or_cohorts": [
L11:     {
L12:       "id": "murine-efficacy",
L13:       "label": "Mouse efficacy cohort",
L14:       "sample_size_or_observations": "78 tumor-bearing mice",
L15:       "description": "Multiple murine tumor models received intratumoral mRNA vaccine plus anti-PD-L1 across pooled repeat experiments."
L16:     },
L17:     {
L18:       "id": "murine-controls",
L19:       "label": "Mouse control cohorts",
L20:       "sample_size_or_observations": "84 tumor-bearing mice",
L21:       "description": "Matched control conditions included vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle arms across pooled murine experiments."
L22:     },
L23:     {
L24:       "id": "human-retrospective",
L25:       "label": "Human retrospective cohort",
L26:       "sample_size_or_observations": "130 patients",
L27:       "description": "Retrospective metastatic patient cohort compared prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status during ICI treatment."
L28:     },
L29:     {
L30:       "id": "human-vaccinated",
L31:       "label": "Vaccinated subgroup",
L32:       "sample_size_or_observations": "43 patients",
L33:       "description": "Patients in the retrospective cohort who had prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination."
L34:     },
L35:     {
L36:       "id": "human-unvaccinated",
L37:       "label": "Unvaccinated subgroup",
L38:       "sample_size_or_observations": "87 patients",
L39:       "description": "Patients in the retrospective cohort without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination for comparison."
L40:     }
L41:   ],
L42:   "major_limitations": [
L43:     "The human analysis was retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is likely.",
L44:     "Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.",
L45:     "Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.",
L46:     "Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.",
L47:     "Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniform across settings."
L48:   ]
L49: }

L46:           "line_ref": "L42"
L47:         }
L48:       ],
L49:       "caveat": "The exact quantitative size of this loss of effect is not provided in the report text, only the directional null result."
L50:     },
L51:     {
L52:       "claim_id": "C04",
L53:       "claim": "In the human retrospective cohort, prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination was associated with improved ICI outcomes compared with no prior vaccination.",
L54:       "strength": "tentative",
L55:       "evidence": [
L56:         {
L57:           "quote": "Retrospective human survival comparison p=0.01",
L58:           "line_ref": "L30"
L59:         },
L60:         {

L1: {
L2:   "headline": "mRNA shots inside tumors may boost checkpoint therapy, but human proof is still preliminary",
L3:   "plain_language_summary": "This study asks whether local delivery of an mRNA vaccine into tumors can make cancers more responsive to immune checkpoint therapy. In mice, the authors report broader antigen presentation, stronger interferon signaling, and greater immune-cell infiltration with the combination strategy, including higher MHC-I peptide coverage and increased PD-L1 signaling. In the human retrospective cohort, vaccinated patients showed a lower survival p-value (p=0.01) than unvaccina
L4:   ,
L5:   "what_is_new": [
L6:     "The work links intratumoral mRNA vaccination to a marked increase in reported tumor immunopeptidome coverage, implying wider antigen display to immune cells.",
L7:     "Type I interferon signaling is proposed as a required driver of sensitization, with mechanistic blocks showing loss of effect when IFNAR1 is inhibited.",
L8:     "The translational signal combines pooled mouse efficacy data with a human retrospective signal (vaccinated subgroup, p=0.01) rather than a randomized clinical endpoint."
L9:   ],
L10:   "why_caution_is_needed": [
L11:     "The human part is retrospective and non-randomized, so confounding and selection bias could influence observed differences.",
L12:     "Vaccination timing around ICI initiation was not standardized, making temporal confounding possible.",
L13:     "Patient tumor mix and prior treatment history were heterogeneous, limiting a direct causal interpretation for all cancer subtypes.",
L14:     "Preclinical models may not fully predict clinical benefit in humans, so translation remains uncertain."
L15:   ],
L16:   "glossary": [
L17:     {
L18:       "term": "mRNA vaccine",
L19:       "definition": "A medicine that delivers genetic instructions so local cells make a specific protein, in this case used to trigger antitumor immune signaling."
L20:     },
L21:     {
L22:       "term": "Immune checkpoint",
L23:       "definition": "A control signal on immune cells; blocking PD-L1 is meant to reduce inhibitory signals and restore T-cell killing of tumors."
L24:     },
L25:     {
L26:       "term": "Interferon",
L27:       "definition": "Immune signaling molecules, especially type I interferons, that activate antiviral and immune-defense programs in nearby cells."
L28:     },
L29:     {
L30:       "term": "MHC-I",
L31:       "definition": "A molecule on cells that presents short peptide fragments to CD8 T cells, helping the immune system detect abnormal targets."
L32:     }
L33:   ],
L34:   "open_questions": [
L35:     "Will the observed sensitization effects persist in prospective randomized human trials with standardized vaccination timing and stratification by tumor type?",
L36:     "Which specific patients, tumor settings, or biomarkers best predict who benefits from intratumoral mRNA priming plus checkpoint blockade?",
L37:     "Can safety, durability of control, and resistance mechanisms be established in patients with non-immunogenic or previously resistant cancers?"
L38:   ]
L39: }

L1: {
L2:   "claims": [
L3:     {
L4:       "claim_id": "C01",
L5:       "claim": "Intratumoral mRNA vaccination can broaden tumor antigen presentation and enhance visibility to T cells via MHC-I pathways.",
L6:       "strength": "strong",
L7:       "evidence": [
L8:         {
L9:           "quote": "Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination",
L10:           "line_ref": "L28"
L11:         },
L12:         {
L13:           "quote": "Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape",
L14:           "line_ref": "L29"
L15:         }
L16:       ],
L17:       "caveat": "The report presents pooled preclinical findings and does not specify whether these gains are uniform across every model tested."
L18:     },
L19:     {
L20:       "claim_id": "C02",
L21:       "claim": "The intervention induces an interferon-rich state that is linked to mechanistic sensitization to checkpoint blockade.",
L22:       "strength": "strong",
L23:       "evidence": [
L24:         {
L25:           "quote": "Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors",
L26:           "line_ref": "L31"
L27:         },
L28:         {
L29:           "quote": "Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.",
L30:           "line_ref": "L42"
L31:         }
L32:       ],
L33:       "caveat": "A causal mediation chain is proposed from expression changes to outcome, but human data are retrospective and observational."
L34:     },
L35:     {
L36:       "claim_id": "C03",
L37:       "claim": "Type I interferon signaling appears necessary for the sensitization effect because anti-IFNAR1 blockade removes benefit.",
L38:       "strength": "strong",
L39:       "evidence": [
L40:         {
L41:           "quote": "Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.",
L42:           "line_ref": "L39"
L43:         },
L44:         {
L45:           "quote": "Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.",
L46:           "line_ref": "L42"
L47:         }
L48:       ],
L49:       "caveat": "The exact quantitative size of this loss of effect is not provided in the report text, only the directional null result."
L50:     },
L51:     {
L52:       "claim_id": "C04",
L53:       "claim": "In the human retrospective cohort, prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination was associated with improved ICI outcomes compared with no prior vaccination.",
L54:       "strength": "tentative",
L55:       "evidence": [
L56:         {
L57:           "quote": "Retrospective human survival comparison p=0.01",
L58:           "line_ref": "L30"
L59:         },
L60:         {
L61:           "quote": "Human retrospective metastatic cohort: 130 patients total.",
L62:           "line_ref": "L21"
L63:         }
L64:       ],
L65:       "caveat": "The authors note that this analysis is retrospective, non-randomized, and subject to residual confounding, including variable timing of vaccination and treatment heterogeneity."
L66:     },
L67:     {
L68:       "claim_id": "C05",
L69:       "claim": "Combined mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 intervention improved tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the human cohort.",
L70:       "strength": "moderate",
L71:       "evidence": [
L72:         {
L73:           "quote": "Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.",
L74:           "line_ref": "L46"
L75:         },
L76:         {
L77:           "quote": "Preclinical arm: multiple murine tumor models with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.",
L78:           "line_ref": "L14"
L79:         }
L80:       ],
L81:       "caveat": "This claim mixes preclinical causal evidence with retrospective human association, so translational strength is suggestive rather than definitive."
L82:     }
L83:   ]
L84: }ggestive rather than definitive."
L85:     }
L86:   ]
L87: }

L1: {
L2:   "paper": {
L3:     "title": "SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade",
L4:     "doi": "10.1038/s41586-025-09006-8",
L5:     "publication_year": 2025,
L6:     "domain": "oncology-immunology",
L7:     "study_type": "preclinical+retrospective"
L8:   },
L9:   "core_question": "Can intratumoral mRNA vaccination sensitize tumors to immune checkpoint blockade and does that align with outcomes in vaccinated patients receiving ICI?",
L10:   "datasets_or_cohorts": [
L11:     {
L12:       "id": "murine-efficacy",
L13:       "label": "Mouse efficacy cohort",
L14:       "sample_size_or_observations": "78 tumor-bearing mice",
L15:       "description": "Multiple murine tumor models received intratumoral mRNA vaccine plus anti-PD-L1 across pooled repeat experiments."
L16:     },
L17:     {
L18:       "id": "murine-controls",
L19:       "label": "Mouse control cohorts",
L20:       "sample_size_or_observations": "84 tumor-bearing mice",
L21:       "description": "Matched control conditions included vaccine-only, ICI-only, and vehicle arms across pooled murine experiments."
L22:     },
L23:     {
L24:       "id": "human-retrospective",
L25:       "label": "Human retrospective cohort",
L26:       "sample_size_or_observations": "130 patients",
L27:       "description": "Retrospective metastatic patient cohort compared prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status during ICI treatment."
L28:     },
L29:     {
L30:       "id": "human-vaccinated",
L31:       "label": "Vaccinated subgroup",
L32:       "sample_size_or_observations": "43 patients",
L33:       "description": "Patients in the retrospective cohort who had prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination."
L34:     },
L35:     {
L36:       "id": "human-unvaccinated",
L37:       "label": "Unvaccinated subgroup",
L38:       "sample_size_or_observations": "87 patients",
L39:       "description": "Patients in the retrospective cohort without prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination for comparison."
L40:     }
L41:   ],
L42:   "major_limitations": [
L43:     "The human analysis was retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding is likely.",
L44:     "Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.",
L45:     "Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.",
L46:     "Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.",
L47:     "Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniform across settings."
L48:   ]
L49: }

L1: {
L2:   "findings": [
L3:     {
L4:       "id": "Q01",
L5:       "metric": "Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome",
L6:       "value": "62.3%",
L7:       "comparator_or_baseline": "37.3% in comparator group",
L8:       "interpretation": "Intratumoral mRNA vaccination was associated with broader antigen display in tumors.",
L9:       "evidence_line_refs": ["L28"]
L10:     },
L11:     {
L12:       "id": "Q02",
L13:       "metric": "Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome",
L14:       "value": "40.6%",
L15:       "comparator_or_baseline": "20.6% in comparator group",
L16:       "interpretation": "Vaccination expanded the MHC-I-presented peptide landscape versus control.",
L17:       "evidence_line_refs": ["L29"]
L18:     },
L19:     {
L20:       "id": "Q03",
L21:       "metric": "Retrospective human survival comparison p-value",
L22:       "value": "p=0.01",
L23:       "comparator_or_baseline": "N/A",
L24:       "interpretation": "The vaccinated subgroup showed a statistically improved survival association under ICI treatment.",
L25:       "evidence_line_refs": ["L30"]
L26:     },
L27:     {
L28:       "id": "Q04",
L29:       "metric": "Type I interferon response score (normalized units)",
L30:       "value": "3.1",
L31:       "comparator_or_baseline": "1.0 baseline",
L32:       "interpretation": "Type I interferon signaling was markedly induced after intratumoral mRNA vaccination.",
L33:       "evidence_line_refs": ["L31"]
L34:     },
L35:     {
L36:       "id": "Q05",
L37:       "metric": "PD-L1 expression fold-change",
L38:       "value": "2.4x",
L39:       "comparator_or_baseline": "1.0x baseline",
L40:       "interpretation": "PD-L1 levels in tumor tissue increased more than two-fold following mRNA vaccination.",
L41:       "evidence_line_refs": ["L32"]
L42:     },
L43:     {
L44:       "id": "Q06",
L45:       "metric": "Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change",
L46:       "value": "1.8x",
L47:       "comparator_or_baseline": "1.0x baseline",
L48:       "interpretation": "CD8+ infiltration increased with combination-related conditions compared with baseline.",
L49:       "evidence_line_refs": ["L33"]
L50:     }
L51:   ],
L52:   "controls_or_null_results": [
L53:     {
L54:       "statement": "Vaccine-only treatment did not produce durable tumor control in non-immunogenic models.",
L55:       "evidence_line_ref": "L36"
L56:     },
L57:     {
L58:       "statement": "ICI-only treatment had limited activity in low-immunogenic baseline settings.",
L59:       "evidence_line_ref": "L37"
L60:     },
L61:     {
L62:       "statement": "Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.",
L63:       "evidence_line_ref": "L38"
L64:     },
L65:     {
L66:       "statement": "Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated sensitization benefit.",
L67:       "evidence_line_ref": "L39"
L68:     }
L69:   ]
L70: }

L1: {
L2:   "claims": [
L3:     {
L4:       "claim_id": "C01",
L5:       "claim": "Intratumoral mRNA vaccination can broaden tumor antigen presentation and enhance visibility to T cells via MHC-I pathways.",
L6:       "strength": "strong",
L7:       "evidence": [
L8:         {
L9:           "quote": "| Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination |",
L10:           "line_ref": "L28"
L11:         },
L12:         {
L13:           "quote": "| Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape |",
L14:           "line_ref": "L29"
L15:         }
L16:       ],
L17:       "caveat": "The report presents pooled preclinical findings and does not specify whether these gains are uniform across every model tested."
L18:     },
L19:     {
L20:       "claim_id": "C02",
L21:       "claim": "The intervention induces an interferon-rich state that is linked to mechanistic sensitization to checkpoint blockade.",
L22:       "strength": "strong",
L23:       "evidence": [
L24:         {
L25:           "quote": "| Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors |",
L26:           "line_ref": "L31"
L27:         },
L28:         {
L29:           "quote": "Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.",
L30:           "line_ref": "L42"
L31:         }
L32:       ],
L33:       "caveat": "A causal mediation chain is proposed from expression changes to outcome, but human data are retrospective and observational."
L34:     },
L35:     {
L36:       "claim_id": "C03",
L37:       "claim": "Type I interferon signaling appears necessary for the sensitization effect because anti-IFNAR1 blockade removes benefit.",
L38:       "strength": "strong",
L39:       "evidence": [
L40:         {
L41:           "quote": "Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.",
L42:           "line_ref": "L39"
L43:         },
L44:         {
L45:           "quote": "Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.",
L46:           "line_ref": "L42"
L47:         }
L48:       ],
L49:       "caveat": "The report indicates directional loss of effect with IFNAR1 blockade, but does not provide quantitative magnitude of that loss."
L50:     },
L51:     {
L52:       "claim_id": "C04",
L53:       "claim": "In the human retrospective cohort, prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination was associated with improved ICI outcomes compared with no prior vaccination.",
L54:       "strength": "tentative",
L55:       "evidence": [
L56:         {
L57:           "quote": "| Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | N/A | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment |",
L58:           "line_ref": "L30"
L59:         },
L60:         {
L61:           "quote": "Human retrospective metastatic cohort: 130 patients total.",
L62:           "line_ref": "L21"
L63:         }
L64:       ],
L65:       "caveat": "The authors caution this analysis is retrospective and non-randomized, so residual confounding and selection bias may influence observed associations."
L66:     },
L67:     {
L68:       "claim_id": "C05",
L69:       "claim": "Combined mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 intervention improved tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the human cohort.",
L70:       "strength": "moderate",
L71:       "evidence": [
L72:         {
L73:           "quote": "Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.",
L74:           "line_ref": "L46"
L75:         },
L76:         {
L77:           "quote": "Preclinical arm: multiple murine tumor models with intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1 combinations.",
L78:           "line_ref": "L14"
L79:         }
L80:       ],
L81:       "caveat": "The human translational signal is retrospective, while the mouse arm is preclinical, so the combined causal interpretation is suggestive not definitive."
L82:     }
L83:   ]
L84: }

L1: {
L2:   "headline": "mRNA shots inside tumors may boost checkpoint therapy, but human proof is still preliminary",
L3:   "plain_language_summary": "This study asks whether local delivery of an mRNA vaccine into tumors can make cancers more responsive to immune checkpoint therapy. In mice, the authors report broader antigen presentation, stronger interferon signaling, and greater immune-cell infiltration with the combination strategy, including higher MHC-I peptide coverage and increased PD-L1 signaling. In the human retrospective cohort, vaccinated patients showed a lower survival p-value (p=0.01) than unvaccina
L4:   ,
L5:   "what_is_new": [
L6:     "The work links intratumoral mRNA vaccination to a marked increase in reported tumor immunopeptidome coverage, implying wider antigen display to immune cells.",
L7:     "Type I interferon signaling is proposed as a required driver of sensitization, with mechanistic blocks showing loss of effect when IFNAR1 is inhibited.",
L8:     "The translational signal combines pooled mouse efficacy data with a human retrospective signal (vaccinated subgroup, p=0.01) rather than a randomized clinical endpoint."
L9:   ],
L10:   "why_caution_is_needed": [
L11:     "The human part is retrospective and non-randomized, so confounding and selection bias could influence observed differences.",
L12:     "Vaccination timing around ICI initiation was not standardized, making temporal confounding possible.",
L13:     "Patient tumor mix and prior treatment history were heterogeneous, limiting a direct causal interpretation for all cancer subtypes.",
L14:     "Preclinical models may not fully predict clinical benefit in humans, so translation remains uncertain."
L15:   ],
L16:   "glossary": [
L17:     {
L18:       "term": "mRNA vaccine",
L19:       "definition": "A medicine that delivers genetic instructions so local cells make a specific protein, in this case used to trigger antitumor immune signaling."
L20:     },
L21:     {
L22:       "term": "Immune checkpoint",
L23:       "definition": "A control signal on immune cells; blocking PD-L1 is meant to reduce inhibitory signals and restore T-cell killing of tumors."
L24:     },
L25:     {
L26:       "term": "Interferon",
L27:       "definition": "Immune signaling molecules, especially type I interferons, that activate antiviral and immune-defense programs in nearby cells."
L28:     },
L29:     {
L30:       "term": "MHC-I",
L31:       "definition": "A molecule on cells that presents short peptide fragments to CD8 T cells, helping the immune system detect abnormal targets."
L32:     }
L33:   ],
L34:   "open_questions": [
L35:     "Will the observed sensitization effects persist in prospective randomized human trials with standardized vaccination timing and stratification by tumor type?",
L36:     "Which specific patients, tumor settings, or biomarkers best predict who benefits from intratumoral mRNA priming plus checkpoint blockade?",
L37:     "Can safety, durability of control, and resistance mechanisms be established in patients with non-immunogenic or previously resistant cancers?"
L38:   ]
L39: }
